title: Sports in Charlotte, North Carolina
text:
Sports in <a href="Charlotte%2C%20North%20Carolina">Charlotte, North Carolina</a> have a long and varied history. The city is home to teams at nearly every level of American sports including the <a href="Carolina%20Panthers">Carolina Panthers</a> of the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> and <a href="Charlotte%20Hornets">Charlotte Hornets</a> of the <a href="National%20Basketball%20Association">National Basketball Association</a>. In addition to serving as the home base for several teams the city plays host to many events of national and international importance including the longest race in <a href="NASCAR">NASCAR</a>, the annual <a href="Coca-Cola%20600">Coca-Cola 600</a> and golf's <a href="Wells%20Fargo%20Championship">Wells Fargo Championship</a>.
Teams and history.
Professional and non-collegiate amateur.
<a href="Baseball">Baseball</a> has been played at a high level in Charlotte since at least 1892 when the <a href="Charlotte%20Hornets%20%28baseball%29">Charlotte Hornets</a> debuted in a competition known as the South Atlantic League, later a team called the Charlotte Presbyterians took part in the North Carolina Association before reverting to the Hornets name and bouncing around a number of leagues until 1972. In 1976 following a short spell with no professional baseball in the city wrestling promoter <a href="Jim%20Crockett%2C%20Jr.">Jim Crockett, Jr.</a> brought the <a href="Charlotte%20O%27s">Charlotte O's</a> to the Charlotte, the O's would later become the modern day Charlotte Knights.
Between 1969 and 1974 <a href="Greensboro%2C%20North%20Carolina">Greensboro's</a> <a href="American%20Basketball%20Association">American Basketball Association</a> team, the <a href="Carolina%20Cougars">Carolina Cougars</a> played a number of home games each season at the original <a href="Bojangles%27%20Coliseum">Charlotte Coliseum</a>, the team would also play games in Raleigh and <a href="Winston-Salem%2C%20North%20Carolina">Winston-Salem</a>. It would be until 1988 that Charlotte would be awarded its first <a href="Major%20professional%20sports%20leagues%20in%20the%20United%20States%20and%20Canada">major league</a> team in the form of the <a href="Charlotte%20Hornets%20%281988%E2%80%932002%29">Charlotte Hornets</a> of the <a href="National%20Basketball%20Association">NBA</a>. The team played out of the 24,000-seat <a href="Charlotte%20Coliseum">Charlotte Coliseum</a>, known affectionately as "The Hive", and would lead the league in attendance for eight seasons before an acrimonious fall out with owner <a href="George%20Shinn">George Shinn</a> triggered a number of events which led to the team relocating to <a href="New%20Orleans">New Orleans</a> in 2002. However, it didn't take long for the Queen City to return to the NBA when a group led by businessman <a href="Robert%20L.%20Johnson">Bob Johnson</a>, the founder of <a href="Black%20Entertainment%20Television">BET</a>, was awarded a franchise which would come to be known as the <a href="Charlotte%20Bobcats">Charlotte Bobcats</a>. In 2013, eleven years after the Hornets left the city, the Bobcats, now playing at the <a href="Spectrum%20Center%20%28arena%29">Spectrum Center</a>, announced the team would assume the city's beloved nickname following the rebranding of the New Orleans team as the Pelicans. Charlotte was also home to a <a href="Women%27s%20National%20Basketball%20Association">WNBA</a> team, the <a href="Charlotte%20Sting">Charlotte Sting</a> from 1988 until they folded in 2006.
The history of professional <a href="American%20football">football</a> in Charlotte began in 1967, when the <a href="American%20Football%20League">American Football League</a> staged a preseason exhibition game between the <a href="Houston%20Oilers">Houston Oilers</a> and the <a href="New%20York%20Jets">New York Jets</a>. Pro football returned under bizarre circumstances following the relocation of a <a href="World%20Football%20League">World Football League</a> team, the <a href="Charlotte%20Hornets%20%28WFL%29">Charlotte Hornets</a>, to the city from New York in the middle of the 1974 season. Disillusioned with life at the dilapidated <a href="Downing%20Stadium">Downing Stadium</a> and saddled with heavy debt from financing renovations to the facility the ownership of the New York Stars sold the franchise to a Charlotte-based group. The Hornets played out of <a href="American%20Legion%20Memorial%20Stadium">American Legion Memorial Stadium</a> and were a moderate success on the field and in the stands but struggled financially and eventually shuttered operations after an abbreviated 1975 season when the entire league shut down. Professional football would return to Charlotte in 1992 in the form of the <a href="Charlotte%20Rage">Charlotte Rage</a>, an <a href="Arena%20Football%20League">Arena Football League</a> team that played out of the Coliseum. The Rage would qualify for the playoffs twice (in 1993 & 1994) before closing in 1996. The Arena League would return to Charlotte in 2003 when the <a href="Carolina%20Cobras">Carolina Cobras</a> relocated from Raleigh. The Cobras short tenure in Charlotte is memorable for appearances by future <a href="Pro%20Bowl">Pro Bowl</a>er <a href="Rob%20Bironas">Rob Bironas</a> and future <a href="WWE">WWE</a> wrestler <a href="Thaddeus%20Bullard">Thaddeus Bullard</a>, better known as Titus O'Neil.
In 1987 businessman <a href="Jerry%20Richardson">Jerry Richardson</a> announced his intentions to bring the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> to <a href="the%20Carolinas">the Carolinas</a> with a bid centered in Charlotte. The Richardson-lead group staged several NFL exhibitions around the Carolinas and in 1991 formally filed an expansion bid which was unanimously approved by the NFL's 28 owners making the <a href="Carolina%20Panthers">Carolina Panthers</a> the 29th NFL franchise. The Panthers spent the <a href="1995%20NFL%20season">1995 season</a> south of the border at <a href="Clemson%20Tigers">Clemson's</a> <a href="Memorial%20Stadium%20%28Clemson%29">Memorial Stadium</a> while <a href="Bank%20of%20America%20Stadium">Bank of America Stadium</a> in Uptown was being prepared for the team's <a href="1996%20NFL%20season">1996 season</a>. To date the Panthers have appeared in two Super Bowls, <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXXVIII">Super Bowl XXXVIII</a> and <a href="Super%20Bowl%2050">Super Bowl 50</a>, and lay claim to four conference championships and six division championships.
Since 2005 Charlotte has been home to a women's football team called the <a href="Carolina%20Queens">Carolina Queens</a>. The Queens play home games at <a href="Hopewell%20High%20School%20%28North%20Carolina%29">Hopewell High</a>'s stadium in <a href="Huntersville%2C%20North%20Carolina">Huntersville</a>.
Despite being a warm-weather, <a href="Southern%20United%20States">Southern</a> city, Charlotte has a long <a href="ice%20hockey">ice hockey</a> history that dates back to 1956 when the <a href="Charlotte%20Checkers%20%281956%E2%80%9377%29">original Charlotte Checkers</a> were formed and began play in the <a href="Eastern%20Hockey%20League">Eastern Hockey League</a>. The Checkers would play in the EHL for several seasons before moving to the more geographically-friendly <a href="Southern%20Hockey%20League%20%281973%E2%80%9377%29">Southern Hockey League</a> where the team would win two championships before folding with the rest of the league in 1977. It would be 17-years before the sport would return to the city at the professional level with the formation of an <a href="ECHL">ECHL</a> team named in honor of the original Charlotte hockey team. The second version of the <a href="Charlotte%20Checkers%20%281993%E2%80%932010%29">Checkers</a> would take up residence at the original Coliseum (then known as Independence Arena) and would quickly become a success by winning the <a href="Kelly%20Cup">Kelly Cup</a> in 1996. The team moved to the <a href="Spectrum%20Center%20%28arena%29">Spectrum Center</a> in 2005. In 2010 the Checkers would move to the <a href="American%20Hockey%20League">American Hockey League</a> and become the top affiliate of Raleigh's <a href="National%20Hockey%20League">National Hockey League</a> team, the <a href="Carolina%20Hurricanes">Carolina Hurricanes</a>. In 2015 the Checkers moved back to the Coliseum.
Throughout the years Charlotte has been home to a number of soccer teams, and is currently home of the <a href="Charlotte%20Eagles">Charlotte Eagles</a> of the <a href="USL%20League%20Two">USL League Two</a>, their sister team, the <a href="Charlotte%20Lady%20Eagles">Charlotte Lady Eagles</a> of the <a href="USL%20W-League">USL W-League</a>, and the <a href="Charlotte%20Independence">Charlotte Independence</a> of the <a href="United%20Soccer%20League">United Soccer League</a>. Both Eagles teams have won a number of championships at the lower-levels of American soccer. In 1981 Charlotte's <a href="American%20Soccer%20League%20%281933%E2%80%9383%29">American Soccer League</a> team, the <a href="Carolina%20Lightnin%27">Carolina Lightnin'</a>, won the league championship before a sold-out Memorial Stadium when they defeated New York United 2–1. <a href="Major%20League%20Soccer">Major League Soccer</a> awarded an <a href="Charlotte%20MLS%20team">expansion team</a> to Charlotte in 2019 that is set to begin play in 2021.
<a href="Lacrosse">Lacrosse</a> is a sport with a relatively short history in Charlotte but one that is experiencing growth following the formation of two professional lacrosse teams. The <a href="Charlotte%20Hounds">Charlotte Hounds</a> are a <a href="field%20lacrosse">field lacrosse</a> team that plays in <a href="Major%20League%20Lacrosse">Major League Lacrosse</a>, the top level of the sport in the United States, out of Memorial Stadium. The Hounds began play in 2012 and were founded by Jim McPhilliamy. Charlotte's other lacrosse team, the <a href="Charlotte%20Copperheads">Charlotte Copperheads</a>, plays the indoor version of the game, <a href="box%20lacrosse">box lacrosse</a>, in the <a href="Professional%20Lacrosse%20League">Professional Lacrosse League</a>.
<a href="Tennis">Tennis</a> is played at several venues throughout Charlotte by both individuals and clubs at the recreational and competitive levels. Charlotte's most prominent tennis venue is the 13-court Jeff Adams Tennis Center at <a href="Renaissance%20Park%20%28Charlotte%2C%20North%20Carolina%29">Renaissance Park</a>.
Charlotte is home to one of <a href="North%20Carolina">North Carolina</a>'s oldest <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> organizations, the <a href="Charlotte%20Rugby%20Club">Charlotte Rugby Club</a>, or the Olde Originals. CRC was founded in 1971 by former <a href="college%20rugby">college rugby</a> players and is based at the Skillbeck Athletic Grounds in Coulwood, a neighborhood in the northwestern portion of the city.
The <a href="Charlotte%20Roller%20Girls">Charlotte Roller Girls</a> organization is a flat-track <a href="roller%20derby">roller derby</a> club that was founded by several local women in 2006 and plays out of the <a href="Grady%20Cole%20Center">Grady Cole Center</a>.
Since 1931, <a href="Jim%20Crockett%20Promotions">Jim Crockett Promotions</a> has been a full-fledged <a href="professional%20wrestling">professional wrestling</a> performer, based in the North Carolina, South Carolina, and Virginia states, and has been called <a href="Mid-Atlantic%20Wrestling">Mid-Atlantic Wrestling</a>. <a href="National%20Wrestling%20Alliance">National Wrestling Alliance</a>, <a href="World%20Championship%20Wrestling">World Championship Wrestling</a>, <a href="WWE">WWE</a> has big matches, and many <a href="pay-per-view">pay-per-view</a> event. Many professional wrestlers living.
Collegiate.
<a href="Mecklenburg%20County%2C%20North%20Carolina">Mecklenburg</a> is home to five <a href="collegiate%20athletics">collegiate athletic</a> programs and is where the offices of the <a href="Big%20South%20Conference">Big South Conference</a> are based.
The <a href="University%20of%20North%20Carolina%20at%20Charlotte">University of North Carolina at Charlotte</a>, founded in 1946 as the Charlotte Center of the University of North Carolina, is the home of 17 varsity teams known as the <a href="Charlotte%2049ers">Charlotte 49ers</a>. Charlotte has full Division I status and is a member of <a href="Conference%20USA">Conference USA</a> and has participated in the <a href="NCAA%20Division%20I%20Men%27s%20Basketball%20Tournament">NCAA Tournament</a> 11 times and appeared in 1 Bowl Game. UNC Charlotte is one of the largest <a href="public%20universities">public universities</a> in the state of North Carolina.
<a href="Davidson%20College">Davidson College</a>, founded in 1837 and based in the <a href="Davidson%2C%20North%20Carolina">eponymous north Mecklenburg town</a>, is the oldest of these institutions and is the home of the <a href="Davidson%20Wildcats">Wildcats</a>. A full <a href="NCAA%20Division%20I">NCAA Division I</a> program, Davidson is a member of the <a href="Atlantic%2010%20Conference">Atlantic 10 Conference</a> and fields 19 varsity teams.
Charlotte and Davidson compete in men's basketball for the Hornets' Nest Trophy. Charlotte leads the all-time series 29-17
<a href="Queens%20University%20of%20Charlotte">Queens University of Charlotte</a> is a private, <a href="Presbyterian">Presbyterian</a> school based in the Charlotte neighborhood of Myers Park. Queens began life in 1857 as the Charlotte Female Institute. In the 1980s Queens began admitting male students. The <a href="Queens%20Royals">Queens Royals</a> play in the <a href="South%20Atlantic%20Conference">South Atlantic Conference</a> at the <a href="NCAA%20Division%20II">NCAA Division II</a> level.
<a href="Johnson%20C.%20Smith%20University">Johnson C. Smith University</a> is an <a href="HBCU">HBCU</a> located near Uptown in Biddleville. JCSU was founded in 1867 and the <a href="JCSU%20Golden%20Bulls">Golden Bulls</a> play at Division II level as a member of the <a href="Central%20Intercollegiate%20Athletic%20Association">Central Intercollegiate Athletic Association</a>.
A newcomer, the Charlotte campus of <a href="Johnson%20%26amp%3B%20Wales%20University">Johnson & Wales University</a> was established in 2004. The <a href="Johnson%20%26amp%3B%20Wales%20University%23Charlotte%20Campus">JWU Wildcats</a> play men's basketball and women's volleyball as independent members of the <a href="United%20States%20Collegiate%20Athletic%20Association">United States Collegiate Athletic Association</a>.
The annual <a href="Central%20Intercollegiate%20Athletic%20Association">CIAA</a> Basketball Tournament was held in Charlotte from 2006-2020. The tournament attracted over 100,000 fans and spectators and had a $55 million economic impact on the city. The sustained success of the tournament led to the CIAA's decision to relocate its headquarters from <a href="Hampton%2C%20Virginia">Hampton, VA</a> to Charlotte in August 2015.
The city is also the home of the <a href="National%20Junior%20College%20Athletic%20Association">National Junior College Athletic Association</a> (NJCAA) headquarters. The NJCAA is the second-largest national intercollegiate athletic organization in the United States with over 500 member schools in 43 states.
High schools.
<a href="Charlotte-Mecklenburg%20Schools">Charlotte-Mecklenburg's</a> high school teams are aligned into the following conferences as assigned by the <a href="North%20Carolina%20High%20School%20Athletic%20Association">North Carolina High School Athletic Association</a>.
Mecklenburg County has long been a superpower in North Carolina high school sports dating back to Garinger's (then known as Charlotte High School) multiple football championships in the 1910s. Garinger in its historic and present day forms would go on to become the earliest of the Charlotte powers in the first half of the 20th century before seeing its fortunes fade in the latter half. Garinger most recently claimed a state championship with its 1989 boys basketball team.
The late 20th and early 21st centuries were marked by the rise of Butler, Independence, and West Charlotte as state football powers. West Charlotte's Lions dominated the state football scene between the mid-80s and 90s, a period during which they won five championships in a ten-year span. The late-90s saw Independence begin a 107-game winning streak that included seven consecutive state championships under coach Tom Knotts. Independence's streak would last until 2007 when <a href="Cincinnati%2C%20Ohio">Cincinnati's</a> <a href="Elder%20High%20School">Elder High School</a> defeated the Patriots 41–34 at <a href="Nippert%20Stadium">Nippert Stadium</a>. Butler and Mallard Creek have recently made appearances in state championship games with Butler claiming three titles.
Garinger and West Charlotte each have five state basketball championships while South Meck has four.
Motorsports.
Along with <a href="Indianapolis">Indianapolis</a>, Charlotte is considered one of the hubs of <a href="American%20motorsports%2C%20North%20Carolina">American motorsports</a> with most <a href="NASCAR">NASCAR</a> teams and several <a href="open%20wheel%20racing">open wheel</a> and <a href="sports%20car%20racing">sports car</a> teams calling Charlotte and the area surrounding it home.
Uptown Charlotte is home of the <a href="NASCAR%20Hall%20of%20Fame">NASCAR Hall of Fame</a> and the now defunct <a href="Charlotte%20Speedway">Charlotte Speedway</a> was the site of the first NASCAR Strictly Stock (a precursor to the modern <a href="NASCAR%20Cup%20Series">NASCAR Cup Series</a>) race on June 19, 1949, <a href="Bob%20Flock">Bob Flock</a> won the pole and <a href="Jim%20Roper">Jim Roper</a> was declared the winner after <a href="Glenn%20Dunaway">Glenn Dunaway</a>'s car failed post-race inspection.
Since then a number of Charlotte-area venues have played host to NASCAR's top series including <a href="Metrolina%20Speedway">Metrolina Speedway</a> on the Metrolina Fairgrounds in Charlotte, and <a href="Charlotte%20Motor%20Speedway">Charlotte Motor Speedway</a> in Concord. CMS hosts three Sprint Cup Series events per year including the <a href="NASCAR%20Sprint%20All-Star%20Race">NASCAR Sprint All-Star Race</a> and has been hosting NASCAR's premier series since 1960.
Events.
As with all of <a href="North%20Carolina">North Carolina</a>, Charlotte is a hotbed of golf and hosts annual events across several tours. The <a href="PGA%20Tour">PGA Tour</a> stops in Charlotte once a year for the <a href="Wells%20Fargo%20Championship">Wells Fargo Championship</a> at the <a href="Quail%20Hollow%20Club">Quail Hollow Club</a> and in 2017 the club will host the 99th <a href="PGA%20Championship">PGA Championship</a>. River Run Country Club in Davidson plays host the <a href="Web.com%20Tour">Web.com Tour</a>'s <a href="Chiquita%20Classic">Chiquita Classic</a> and Raintree Country Club is the home of the <a href="Symetra%20Classic">Symetra Classic</a>, an event on the <a href="LPGA">LPGA</a>'s developmental <a href="Symetra%20Tour">Symetra Tour</a>.
The <a href="U.S.%20National%20Whitewater%20Center">U.S. National Whitewater Center</a> is an official <a href="United%20States%20Olympic%20Committee">United States Olympic Committee</a> training site for whitewater <a href="Slalom%20canoeing">slalom</a> racing and has hosted <a href="Olympic%20Summer%20Games">Olympic</a> team qualifying events.
The <a href="Belk%20Bowl">Belk Bowl</a> is played every December in Charlotte and features teams from the <a href="Atlantic%20Coast%20Conference">Atlantic Coast Conference</a> and <a href="Southeastern%20Conference">Southeastern Conference</a>.
<a href="Brooklandwood">Brooklandwood</a> in the nearby Union County town of <a href="Mineral%20Springs%2C%20North%20Carolina">Mineral Springs</a> is the site of the <a href="Queens%20Cup%20Steeplechase">Queens Cup Steeplechase</a>, one of <a href="Steeplechase%20%28horse%20racing%29">steeplechase</a> horse racing's major annual events. The program consists of several races, and is held the last Saturday of April and also features a <a href="Jack%20Russell%20Terrier">Jack Russell Terrier</a> judging contest.
Several cycling events take place in Charlotte including the <a href="Presbyterian%20Hospital%20Invitational%20Criterium">Presbyterian Hospital Invitational Criterium</a> and 24-Hours of Booty.
